newsitem.title: USA: Texas opposes immunity in tobacco settlement.
newsitem.headline: Texas opposes immunity in tobacco settlement.

text.p: Texas Attorney General Dan Morales said on Monday he would oppose any settlement with tobacco companies that would give them immunity from future legal action.
He said in a letter to members of the Texas Legislature the tobacco industry did not deserve immunity because it "has reneged on every promise it has ever made to the American people.
"If there is any industry undeserving of immunity from future liability, it is the tobacco industry," Morales wrote.
Cigarrette makers and anti-tobacco leaders have been in talks recently to reach a settlement that would resolve a multitude of anti-tobacco lawsuits in the United States.
News reports have said the tobacco industry might pay up to $300 billion over 25 years to compensate smokers with tobacco-related ills in exchange for broad protection from legal action.

Morales filed a lawsuit in March 1996 year on behalf of the state of Texas seeking $4 billion in damages from tobacco companies to recoup Medicaid costs of smokers. Similar suits have been filed in 23 states.
The Texas case is scheduled for trial in September in federal court in Texarkana, Texas.
Morales said in his letter that he was "very encouraged" by the recent talks but said "Texas will not be a party to any settlement" that includes tobacco industry legal immunity.
"Under our system of justice, one may not buy the right to violate the law. This basic principle of accountability must not be compromised -- at any price," Morales said.
